awd_titl_txt: Communication between Probation and Parole Agents and their Clients
awd_abstract_narration:
In recent decades the growth in the number of people on probation, on parole, in jail, and in prison has required increased public expenditures, often limiting funds available for other essential services such as education and health care.  Effective community supervision (i.e., probation and parole) offers the possibility of containing these costs when it keeps people out of jail and prison, increases their employment, and promotes individual and community health and welfare. One of the main ways that probation and parole officers can influence offenders is through the discussions that occur during supervision.  However, compared to knowledge about how doctors and other medical and mental health professionals interact effectively with patients, little is known about ways to increase the positive impact that probation and parole officers can have on offenders.  Prior research on women who are supervised in the community has shown that when supervising officers give offenders the information they need to establish a prosocial lifestyle (e.g., strategies to find jobs or avoid substance misuse), it reduces supervision failures and limits costs. It also showed that having a two-way conversation with offenders increased their compliance with requirements. The main goal of this research is to determine the specific forms of communication that are effective for both male and female offenders.  This goal is important because (1) men and women on supervision face different problems, and (2) research has shown that men and women often respond differently to the same messages.  In addition, because people who are under community supervision are disproportionately African American, the study also examines differences in effective communication for men and women from minority versus majority groups.  This knowledge is essential for making efficient use of community supervision resources and for developing educational and training programs.    

The study uses communication and psychological theories and research methods to gain a better understanding of effective officer-offender communication. It examines both officer and offender perceptions of supervision interactions and tests for gender and race differences in those perceptions. The study addresses the key questions: (1) Do the content and manner of communication predict subsequent positive and negative behavior? (2) Is the effect of communication on outcomes different for gender and racial groups? In particular, the focus is on communication about three areas critical to reducing recidivism: employment, substance misuse, and contact with people who break the law. The research also includes an experiment testing whether, for example, informational-oriented messages are more effective if they support the offender's autonomy.  Finally, the study identifies messages from supervising officers that have lasting positive effects on offenders' actions. To address these questions, ninety supervising officers and 300 men and 300 women from their caseloads will be studied. Officers will complete two on-line surveys and offenders will complete two interviews, both at six-month intervals. Official sources will be used to gather criminal history data, data on supervision intensity, non-compliance with supervision requirements, new arrests, and new convictions. Including both officer and offender perspectives as well as official data will provide unique insights into the supervision process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Communication between Probation and Parole Agents and their Clients

 

This report presents key findings from research informed by theories of communication. For 289 people on probation or parole, the study tested how the communication clients reported engaging in with their agents affected them. We also looked at how clients’ gender influenced the communication they reported having with their agents and its effects. Findings show that regardless of gender, clients react positively when agents use a conversational approach, or an open discussion of ideas, and avoid a conformity approach, or direct orders of how to act during discussions. We also found that clients felt better when agents sent supportive messages that attended to clients’ emotions.

 

Psychological Reactions to Communicating with the Supervising Agent

 

Anxiety and reactance are undesirable outcomes of interaction that can promote illegal behavior, and increases in self-efficacy are desirable outcomes that can promote prosocial behavior. Anxiety refers to feelings of worry or distress, whereas reactance occurs when people resist others’ attempts to influence their behavior. Self-efficacy refers to clients’ beliefs that they can engage in productive behavior to achieve their goals (here, we examine self-efficacy to avoid substance misuse, avoid people who break the law, and find employment). Notably, none of the findings below differ for gender groups.

 

Anxiety. When clients see their discussions with agents as more conversational, they report less anxiety after talking to the agent. Alternatively, when clients experience conformity-oriented conversations, they report more anxiety. 

 

Reactance. Conversational patterns of agent to client communication are connected to low levels of reactance. There is a relatively strong connection of conformity communication to high levels of reactance. 

 

Self-efficacy to address substance misuse. Forty-four individuals said they had a problem with substance misuse. In this group, there is a strong connection between a conversational pattern of communication and a self-reported increase in self-efficacy to address this problem after talking with their supervising agent. A conformity communication pattern was negatively related to self-efficacy, though this was a relatively weak relationship. 

 

Self-efficacy to avoid people who break the law. For 84 individuals who indicated difficulty in avoiding people who broke the law, the connection between a conversational communication pattern and increased efficacy to address the problem is strong. A conformity communication pattern was unrelated to self-efficacy to avoid people who break the law.

 

Self-efficacy to find employment. A total of 167 individuals said they had some difficulty finding employment, and in this group, conversational communication was strongly related to increased self-efficacy in addressing this problem after talking to the agent. The use of a conformity pattern had no effect on employment-related self-efficacy.

 

Experimental Findings Re: Effects of Supportive Message Quality

 

Agents provide messages to help their clients, which can include messages intended to relieve clients’ distress (emotional support), and messages intended to enhance clients’ self-esteem (esteem support). To provide emotional support, agents can send messages that validate how the client feels about issues such as difficulty finding employment. For example, an agent could say something like “Of course you’re worried about your job situation – it’s a difficult situation for you to be in when you’re trying to get back on your feet. Know that I’m here for you.” In contrast, they can send a message that criticizes how the client is feeling, “Listen, just stop worrying about your criminal record and how it affects getting or keeping a job.  It’s just not worth worrying.” Study participants rated both validating and critical messages on whether they believed what the agent said would alleviate their distress, for example, how much they agreed with the statement, “You would feel less upset.”  Overall, people under supervision rated the validating messages as most effective. When the messages were critical, White and female clients were especially likely to rate them as ineffective. 

To boost a person’s self-esteem, messages can have a low emotion focus, for example, “The job market is just really bad these days. It’ll all be okay.” Alternatively, they can have a high emotion focus, “I’m proud of the work you’re doing to find and keep a job. You have what it takes to keep working hard.” Study participants indicated that the high emotion focused messages were related to an increase in self-esteem. 

Memorable Messages

 

Agents communicate messages that clients recall for a long time and that can influence prosocial behavior. The most frequent type of memorable message recalled from agents was behavioral advice.  These messages include instructions for what the client should or should not do such as “Keep your nose clean.” They are generally positively received but sometimes cause reactance.  Minorities are most likely to recall these behavioral advice messages.   

 

The second most frequently received messages, motivation messages or encouragement, were recalled fairly evenly across gender groups, as were personal compliments and praise. These messages are uniformly well-received, and therefore considered positive.
